results.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018) burgundy Valentine’s Day dress and picnic dresses design materials
results.brief_description: Edie Kurzer designed the bright burgundy exterior of Mrs Appleyard’s (Natalie Dormer) dress to gives way to a dark underskirt and shirt, with the suggestion that it can be worn with a sunhat and sunglasses in less formal scenes.

constellations_other.name: Clothing, country, character
constellations_other.description: Edie Kurzer's costume design work on Judy & Punch and Picnic at Hanging Rock is part of a larger trend in Australian films and TV series.

results.title_for_label: Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018) burgundy Valentine’s Day dress design materials
results.description: Edie Kurzer’s sketches demonstrate the level of detail and care that goes into each of the costumes in Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018). The time frame of the series is limited, and costumes recur in flashbacks and memories throughout the show. As a result, we can see that each costume was designed to be worn in several ways. Here, we see that the bright burgundy exterior of Mrs Appleyard’s (Natalie Dormer) dress, which she wears in the infamous Valentine’s Day photo, gives way to a dark underskirt and shirt, with the suggestion that it can be worn with a sunhat and sunglasses in less formal scenes.
description_for_label: Edie Kurzer’s sketches demonstrate the level of detail and care that goes into each of the costumes in Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018). The time frame of the series is limited, and costumes recur in flashbacks and memories throughout the show. As a result, we can see that each costume was designed to be worn in several ways. Here, we see that the bright burgundy exterior of Mrs Appleyard’s (Natalie Dormer) dress, which she wears in the infamous Valentine’s Day photo, gives way to a dark underskirt and shirt, with the suggestion that it can be worn with a sunhat and sunglasses in less formal scenes.

results.title: Phi Phi Island after the Indian Ocean tsunami
results.brief_description: How the media produces news changed dramatically when bystanders captured the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami on handheld cameras. After obtaining the footage, news outlets circulated it around the globe. Today, social media allows spectators to share footage and images of world events instantly.

constellations_primary.name: Representing disasters
constellations_primary.description: The devastating Indian Ocean tsunami was captured by many people on personal devices and home cameras, with the footage broadcast to the world. The event also inspired feature films that are part of a long tradition of disaster films, which often push the boundaries of VFX.

constellations_other.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_other.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.title_for_label: Phi Phi Island after the Indian Ocean tsunami
results.description: How the media produces news changed dramatically when bystanders captured the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami on handheld cameras. After obtaining the footage, news outlets circulated it around the globe. Today, social media allows spectators to share footage and images of world events instantly.

results.title: Phenakistiscope discs
results.brief_description: The phenakistoscope is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc is fitted to the device and when seen through the slots, comes to life.

constellations_primary.name: Defying gravity (phenakistoscope)
constellations_primary.description: Walking on the walls and dancing on the ceiling.

results.description:
This is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc featuring a sequence of slightly different pictures is mounted on a handle. Around the disc’s rim, above the images, are equally spaced slots. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistiscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.
description_for_label:
This is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc featuring a sequence of slightly different pictures is mounted on a handle. Around the disc’s rim, above the images, are equally spaced slots. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistiscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.
